form.missing-required-fields: Please fill out the required fields

network.account-conflict: An account with that ID already exists
network.bad-gateway: The CORS policy for this site does not allow access from the specified Origin.
network.bad-method: That method is not allowed here. What are you trying to do?
network.expired-token: You must sign in again in order to proceed
network.not-implemented: That feature is not implemented yet
network.unknown: Not sure what went wrong. Try again maybe?

debug.account-but-no-transaction: We have an account, but no transaction.
debug.count-one-transaction: There is 1 transaction in the cache.
debug.count-all-transactions: There are {n} transactions in the cache.

footer.license: This project is licensed under the {name}.
footer.pr: Feel free to {issue} or submit a pull request on this project's {github}.

accountability.heading: Accountable To Yourself.
accountability.p1: Keep a close eye on your spending. Never lose a dime again! If you're the sort to obsess about where your money is going, {tool}.
accountability.tool: this might be the tool for you

encrypted.heading: Your Ledger, Not Mine.
encrypted.p1: Accountable, by design, cannot see your data, even on our own servers. We don't need or want to see what you do with your money. That's not my job. {legal}
encrypted.legal: (I'd rather you {not} do illegal stuff with this.)

open-source.heading: Keep Me Accountable.
open-source.open: All of Accountable's source code is open to read.
open-source.let-me-know: Let me know if anything needs fixed.

login.cookie-disclaimer: Logging in will set one cookie, which contains your login token. This cookie lets your browser securely remember that you were logged in without Accountable needing to keep your login token someplace unsafe.

new-account-prompt.open-soon: Don't have an account? We'll be open for new accounts soonâ„¢

new-account.heading: Your New Account
new-account.p1: This is your new account ID. You will need it and your passphrase to log in later.
new-account.no-recovery: If you lose it, we won't be able to get it back for you.
new-account.is-account-id-safe: Do you have your account ID ({accountId}) written down somewhere safe?

locked.heading: You're logged in, but your ledger is locked. Enter your passphrase to unlock the ledger.

service.heading: Hosted Service
service.p1: There's an Accountable client-server architecture right here! Click the {login} link above to create an account.

self.heading: Self-host Server
self.p1: Check out the {readme} for more on how to set Accountable up on your own computer.
self.planning: We're planning a hosted solution right here soon.
self.p2: I'm toying with the idea of (optionally) using Firebase as an Accountable server. This would be great for users who are okay with using a Google service and don't want to pay to host your own installation.

goals.heading: Goals
goals.p1: The aim of Accountable is to be a cross-platform and portable spot to keep your transaction records and receipts. I plan to have proper mobile clients eventually. The {selfhost} option will always be available, and I intend for this project to always be {opensource}. You will always have access to the financial records that you give to Accountable, and Accountable cannot share those records with anyone else.

alternatives.heading: Alternatives
alternatives.p1: There are a few {alts} out there, but none I've found that I like. Lots of proprietary ones, too. Feel free to use them if you'd like, I'm not sponsored by any of them. Their respective names are trademarks of their owners:
alternatives.alt2: {intuit} makes {mint}. These guys also make {turbotax} and other fintech products you might have heard about.
alternatives.alt3: {ramsey} makes {everydollar}. I subscribe to many of Ramsey's financial principles. Stay out of debt, folks.
alternatives.alt4: There are {others}, but I've only tried these. Check them out if you're curious! I'm sure they're great.
alternatives.open-source: I'm sure these are brilliant, but none of them are {opensource}. All of these keep your data for you, and hang onto the encryption keys to that data; they're not {e2ee}. I don't know what all they do with your data, and I don't trust them to tell you.
alternatives.summary: Part of their business model is to be the gateway to your financial records. If you just want help with your budget, and want someone else to keep your pocketbook for you, then any of the above may suit you just fine.

security-faq.heading: Security FAQs
security-faq.summary: {tldr} Your data is unreadable by anyone but you (as far as I know.)

encryption-kind.question: What sort of encryption does Accountable do?
encryption-kind.answer: We use only the best {mge} everyone else uses.

where-keys.question: Who holds the encryption keys?
where-keys.answer2: When you create an account, Accountable generates a data-encryption key {dek} to use to encrypt and decrypt your data. Accountable generates a separate key-encryption key {kek} from your given passphrase to use to encrypt your DEK. Accountable then encrypts the DEK and sends it to our servers to store. This encrypted blob is useless without the KEK to decrypt it, and your KEK is unknown without your passphrase.
where-keys.answer3: We use {sha512} and {pbkdf2} with 10,000 rounds to generate these keys. See {source}.

passphrase-handling.question: What does Accountable do with my passphrase?
passphrase-handling.answer1: Accountable never transmits your passphrase anywhere, even over TLS.
passphrase-handling.answer2: Accountable generates a one-way hash of your passphrase, and sends that instead. The server then {salts} and {hashes} that hash, and stores the resulting mash. (That mash has nothing to do with how your data is encrypted; see above.)
passphrase-handling.answer3: When you log in again, Accountable repeats the procedure on your hashed passphrase, and checks to see whether this new mash matches the stored mash.
passphrase-handling.answer4: This mash is what Accountable's server uses to guard access to your encrypted database. If someone can give the server a passphrase hash that results in the correct mash, the server assumes that person is you, and happily sends over your encrypted data. No part of this mashâ€”the hash the server gets, the salt the server generates, or the final mash of the twoâ€”can be used to decrypt your data. (Accountable uses your {dek} for that; see above.)
passphrase-handling.answer5: We use {sha512} and {bcrypt} with a cost factor of 15. See {source}.

change-passphrase.question: What if I change my passphrase?
change-passphrase.answer1: We don't re-encrypt the entire database, if that's what you're thinking.
change-passphrase.answer2: Since your passphrase is only used to generate a KEK, Accountable only re-encrypts the DEK using the new KEK that your new passphrase generates.
change-passphrase.answer3: If you think your DEK may be compromised, I'm sorry. You may export your data, delete your old account, create a new account, and import your data again. This will re-encrypt everything using a fresh DEK.

lost-passphrase.question: What happens if I lose my passphrase?
lost-passphrase.answer1: You lose your data. There is nothing I or anyone can do (unless your passphrase is easily-cracked. Give it a go!) Without your passphrase, nobody can generate the KEK that encrypts the DEK that encrypts your data. Without that passphrase, your data is lost.

database-breach.question: What happens if someone steals the database?
database-breach.answer1: If your passphrase is good, there's nothing anyone but you can do with Accountable's database. The server never sees your DEK, its corresponding KEK, or your passphrase, and cannot put those into the database.
